{{Occupational hazards}}
'''Hazard elimination''' is a hazard control strategy based on completely removing a material or process causing a hazard. Elimination is the most effective of the five members of the [[hierarchy of hazard controls]] in protecting workers, and where possible should be implemented before all other control methods.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/hierarchy/|title=Hierarchy of Controls|last=|first=|date=2016-07-18|website=U.S. [[National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health]]|language=en-us|access-date=2017-03-09}}</ref><ref name="NYCOSH">{{cite web|url=http://nycosh.org/index.php?page=Hierarchy-of-Hazard-Controls|title=Hierarchy of Hazard Controls|last=|first=|date=|website=New York Committee for Occupational Safety & Health|publisher=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120305133129/http://nycosh.org/index.php?page=Hierarchy-of-Hazard-Controls|archive-date=2012-03-05|dead-url=yes|accessdate=2017-03-14}}</ref><ref name="OHS answers">{{cite web|url=http://www.ccohs.ca/oshanswers/hsprograms/hazard_control.html|title=Hazard Control|last=|first=|date=2006-04-20|website=[[Canadian Centre for Occupational Health and Safety]]|publisher=|accessdate=2017-03-14}}</ref> Many jurisdictions require that an employer eliminate hazards if it is possible, before considering other types of hazard control.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hsaa.ca/effective-representation/hazard-identification-elimination-and-control|title=Hazard Identification, Elimination and Control|last=|first=|date=|website=Health Sciences Association of Alberta|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170314062833/https://www.hsaa.ca/effective-representation/hazard-identification-elimination-and-control|archive-date=2017-03-14|dead-url=yes|access-date=2017-03-13|df=}}</ref><ref name=":2" />
Elimination is most effective early in the design process, when it may be inexpensive and simple to implement. It is more difficult to implement for an existing process, when major changes in equipment and procedures may be required.<ref name=":1" /> Elimination can fail as a strategy if the hazardous process or material is reintroduced at a later stage in the design or production phases.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://machinerysafety101.com/2011/02/28/understanding-the-hierarchy-of-controls/|title=Understanding the Hierarchy of Controls|last=Nix|first=Doug|date=2011-02-28|website=Machinery Safety 101|access-date=2017-03-10}}</ref>
The complete elimination of hazards is a major component to the philosophy of [[Prevention through design|Prevention through Design]], which promotes the practice of eliminating hazards at the earliest design stages of a project.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/ptd/|title=Prevention through Design|last=|first=|date=2016-07-29|website=U.S. National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health|language=en-us|access-date=2017-03-09}}</ref> Complete elimination of a hazard is often the most difficult control to achieve, but addressing it at the start of a project allows designers and planners to make large changes much more easily without the need to retrofit or redo work.
== Typical examples == Removing the use of a hazardous chemical is an example of elimination.<ref name="NYCOSH" /> Some substances are difficult or impossible to eliminate because they have unique properties necessary to the process, but it may be possible to instead substitute less hazardous versions of the substance.<ref name=":0" /> Elimination also applies to equipment as well. For example, [[Health effects from noise|noisy]] equipment can be removed from a room used for other purposes,<ref name="saunions">{{cite web|url=http://www.saunions.org.au/ohs/hierachy_of_controls.htm|title=Hierarchy of Controls|last=|first=|date=|website=[[SA Unions]]|publisher=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050623055058/http://www.saunions.org.au/ohs/hierachy_of_controls.htm|archive-date=2005-06-23|dead-url=yes|accessdate=2017-03-14}}</ref> or an unnecessary blade can be removed from a machine.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://simplifiedsafety.com/blog/the-hierarchy-of-controls-part-one-elimination-and-substitution/|title=The Hierarchy of Controls, Part One: Elimination and Substitution|last=Braun|first=John|date=|website=Simplified Safety Fall Protection Blog|access-date=2017-03-10}}</ref> Prompt repair of damaged equipment eliminates hazards stemming from their malfunction.<ref name="saunions" />
Elimination also applies to processes. For example, the risk of [[Falling (accident)|falls]] can be eliminated by eliminating the process of working in a high area, by using extending tools from the ground instead of climbing,<ref name="hse UK">{{cite web|url=http://www.hse.gov.uk/treework/safety-topics/height.htm#control|title=Tree Work – Working at height|last=|first=|date=|website=UK [[Health and Safety Executive]]|publisher=|accessdate=2017-03-14}}</ref> or moving a piece to be worked on to ground level.<ref name="NYCOSH" /> The need for workers to enter a hazardous area such as a [[grain elevator]] can be eliminated by installing equipment that performs the task automatically.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://progressivesafety.us/uncategorized/hierarchy-of-controls-prioritizes-action-on-workplace-hazards/|title=Hierarchy of Controls Prioritizes Action on Workplace Hazards|last=Mlynek|first=Joe|date=|work=Progressive Safety Services|access-date=2017-03-10|language=en-US}}</ref> Eliminating an inspection that requires opening a package containing a hazardous material reduces the inhalation hazard to the inspector.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/docs/2014-102/default.html|title=Current Strategies for Engineering Controls in Nanomaterial Production and Downstream Handling Processes|last=|first=|date=November 2013|website=U.S. National Institute for Occupational Safety and Haalth|pages=9–10|language=en-us|access-date=2017-03-05}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:Industrial hygiene]] [[Category:Safety engineering]] [[Category:Risk analysis]]

'''Human milk oligosaccharides''' (HMO, also known as human milk glycans) are sugar molecules, that are part of the oligosaccharides group and which can be found in high concentrations exclusively in [[Breast milk|human breast milk]]. <ref name=":0">L. Bode: ''Human milk oligosaccharides: every baby needs a sugar mama.'' In: ''Glycobiology.'' Band 22, Nummer 9, September 2012, S. 1147–1162, {{DOI|10.1093/glycob/cws074}}, {{PMID|22513036}}, {{PMC|3406618}}</ref>
==Occurrence== Human milk oligosaccharides form the third most abundant solid component ([[Solution|dissolved]] or [[Emulsion|emulsified]] or [[Suspension (chemistry)|suspended]] in water) of human milk after [[lactose]] and [[fat]].<ref>X. Chen: ''Human Milk Oligosaccharides (HMOS): Structure, Function, and Enzyme-Catalyzed Synthesis.'' In: ''Advances in carbohydrate chemistry and biochemistry.'' Band 72, 2015, S. 113–190, {{DOI|10.1016/bs.accb.2015.08.002}}, {{PMID|26613816}}.</ref> HMOs are present in a concentration of 0.35 - 0.88 oz / L. Approximately 200 structurally different human milk oligosaccharides are known. The composition of human milk oligosaccharides in breast milk is individual to each mother and varies over the [[Breastfeeding|period of lactation]]. The dominant oligosaccharide in 80% of all women is [[2'-Fucosyllactose|2'-fucosyllactose]], which is present in human breast milk at a concentration of approximately 0.088 oz/ L.<ref name=":1">{{citation/core|Surname1=Katja Parschat, Bettina Gutiérrez|Periodical=[[dei – die ernährungsindustrie]]|Title=Fermentativ erzeugte humane Milch-Oligosaccharide wirken präbiotisch.|At=p. 38|Date=2016-11|language=German }}</ref>
==Characteristics== In contrast to the other components of breast milk that are absorbed by the infant through breastfeeding, HMOs are [[Digestion|indigestible]] for the newborn child. However, they have a [[Prebiotic (nutrition)|prebiotic]] effect and serve as food for intestinal bacteria, especially [[Bifidobacterium|bifidobacteria]].<ref>K. Le Doare, B. Holder, A. Bassett, P. S. Pannaraj: ''Mother's Milk: A Purposeful Contribution to the Development of the Infant Microbiota and Immunity.'' In: ''Frontiers in immunology.'' Band 9, 2018, S. 361, {{DOI|10.3389/fimmu.2018.00361}}, {{PMID|29599768}}, {{PMC|5863526}}.</ref> The dominance of these intestinal bacteria in the gut reduces the colonization with [[Pathogen#Pathogenicity|pathogenic]] [[bacteria]] (probiosis) and thereby ensures a healthy [[Gut flora#Intestinal flora|intestinal flora]] (intestinal microbiome) and a reduced risk of dangerous intestinal infections.
Recent studies also suggest that HMOs significantly lower the risk of viral and bacterial [[Infection|infections]] and thus diminish the chance to get diarrhoea and respiratory diseases.
This protective function of the HMOs is activated when in contact with specific [[Pathogen|pathogens]], such as certain bacteria or [[Virus|viruses]]. These have the ability to bind themselves to the glycan [[Receptor (biochemistry)|receptors]] (receptors for long chains of connected sugar molecules on the surface of human cells) located on the surface of the intestinal cells and can thereby infect the cells of the [[Intestinal epithelium|intestinal mucosa]]. Researchers have discovered that HMOs mimic these glycan receptors so the pathogens bind themselves to the HMOs rather than the intestinal cells. This reduces the risk of an infection with a pathogen.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> In addition to this, HMOs seem to influence the reaction of specific cells of the [[immune system]] in a way that reduces [[Inflammation|inflammatory]] responses.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2">D. S. Newburg, Y. He: ''Neonatal Gut Microbiota and Human Milk Glycans Cooperate to Attenuate Infection and Inflammation.'' In: ''Clinical obstetrics and gynecology.'' Band 58, Nummer 4, Dezember 2015, S. 814–826, {{DOI|10.1097/GRF.0000000000000156}}, {{PMID|26457857}}.</ref> It is also suspected that HMOs reduce the risk of [[Preterm birth|premature infants]] becoming infected with the potentially life-threatening disease [[necrotizing enterocolitis]] (NEC).<ref name=":0" />
Some of the [[Metabolite|metabolites]] directly affect the [[nervous system]] or the [[brain]] and can sometimes influence the development and behavior of children in the long term. There are studies that indicate certain HMOs supply the child with [[sialic acid]] residues. Sialic acid is an [[Nutrient#Essential nutrients|essential nutrient]] for the development of the child’s brain and mental abilities.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" />
HMOs are used as supplements in [[baby food]] to ensure a provision of babies that are not being breastfed with this important component of the human milk.<ref>{{citation/core|Surname1=Ralph Ammann|Periodical=European Dairy Magazine|Title=Achieving the impossible|At=pp. 30 f.|Date=2017-05|language=German }}</ref>
==Evolution== In experiments designed to test the suitability of HMOs as a prebiotic source of carbon for intestinal bacteria it was discovered that they are highly selective for a commensal bacteria known as ''[[Bifidobacterium longum|Bifidobacteria longum biovar infantis]]''. The presence of genes unique to ''[[Bifidobacterium longum|B. infantis]]'', including co-regulated glycosidases, and its efficiency at using HMOs as a carbon source may imply a co-evolution of HMOs and the genetic capability of select bacteria to utilize them.<ref name="HMO-EVOLUTION">{{cite journal|last=German|first=JB|last2=Lebrilla|first2=CB|last3=Mills|first3=DA|date=18 Apr 2012|title=Human milk oligosaccharides: evolution, structures and bioselectivity as substrates for intestinal bacteria|journal=Nestle Nutr Workshop Ser Pediatr Program|series=Nestlé Nutrition Workshop Series: Pediatric Program|publisher=|volume=62|issue=|pages=205–22|doi=10.1159/000146322|isbn=978-3-8055-8553-8|pmc=2861563|pmid=18626202}}</ref>

Lakeland College
(1956–2016) | nickname = [https://lakelandmuskies.com/ Muskies] | website = {{URL|lakeland.edu}} | logo = [[File:Lakeland University logo.svg|250px]] }} '''Lakeland University''' is a [[liberal arts college]] with its main campus located in [[Plymouth, Wisconsin]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/milwaukee/news/2018/05/25/lakeland-university-launching-food-safety-and.html|title=Lakeland University launching food safety and quality major based on employer demand|last=Leary|first=Patrick|date=25 May 2018|website=www.bizjournals.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-23}} Lakeland University is affiliated with the [[United Church of Christ]] and offers both undergraduate and graduate degrees.{{Cite web|url=https://lakeland.edu/About-Us/about-us|title=About Us|website=lakeland.edu|access-date=2018-08-23}} Lakeland also has seven evening, weekend, and online centers located throughout the state of Wisconsin—in [[Milwaukee]], [[Madison, Wisconsin|Madison]], [[Wisconsin Rapids, Wisconsin|Wisconsin Rapids]], [[Chippewa Falls, Wisconsin|Chippewa Falls]], [[Neenah, Wisconsin|Neenah]], [[Green Bay, Wisconsin|Green Bay]], and [[Sheboygan, Wisconsin|Sheboygan]]—and a two-year international campus in [[Tokyo]].{{Cite news|url=http://okinawa.stripes.com/education/lakeland-college-japan-acquires-university-status|title=Lakeland College Japan Acquires University Status {{!}} Stripes Okinawa|date=2016-06-28|access-date=2018-08-23|language=en}} ==History== Lakeland traces its beginnings to German immigrants who, seeking a new life, traveled to America and settled in the Sheboygan area.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/milwaukee/stories/2010/02/22/focus24.html|title=Lakeland College|last=|first=|date=21 February 2010|website=www.bizjournals.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-23}} Here are some milestones in the college’s history: * In 1862, the founders built Missionshaus (Mission House), a combined academy-college-seminary. The school was called Mission House College and Seminary until 1956 when it adopted the name Lakeland College.{{Cite news|url=https://fox11online.com/news/local/lakeshore/lakeland-college-to-be-called-lakeland-university|title=Lakeland College to be called Lakeland University|last=News|first=FOX 11|work=WLUK|access-date=2018-08-23|language=en-US}} * In 1956, the college adopted the name Lakeland and began focusing on a liberal arts education. The seminary combined with the Yankton Theological School to become United Theological Seminary of the Twin Cities and relocated to Minneapolis/St. Paul in 1962.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wisconsinhistory.org/Records/Article/CS1773|title=Reformed Churches in Wisconsin {{!}} Wisconsin Historical Society|date=2012-08-03|work=Wisconsin Historical Society|access-date=2018-08-23|language=Sheboygan}} * In 1978, Lakeland launched the state’s first degree-completion program for working adults by offering evening classes.{{Cite news|url=http://www.hngnews.com/sun_prairie_star/community/article_5f8032d0-f04e-5a7b-b7a7-7d449426148a.html|title=Lakeland College celebrates 30 years of adult education at Madison Center|work=Hometown News LP|access-date=2018-08-23|language=en}} Today, Lakeland’s Evening, Weekend & Online program enrolls more than 2,000 graduate and undergraduate students.{{Cite news|url=https://issuu.com/lcmuskies/docs/lakeland-fall-2016|title=Lakeland Fall 2016|work=Issuu|access-date=2018-08-23|language=en}} * In 1991, Lakeland founded a campus in Tokyo, Japan and in 2005 it was recognized as an overseas campus, allowing it to sponsor visas for students. * On July 1, 2016, Lakeland College became Lakeland University. This change resulted in the creation of three schools, a School of Business & Entrepreneurship; a School of Science, Technology & Education; and a School of Humanities and Fine Arts as well as new academic offerings. The change was fueled by many factors, including desire to increase international recruitment and clear up confusion with [[Lakeshore Technical College]], a neighboring institution.{{Cite web|url=https://lakeland.edu/Lakeland-News/lakeland-college-to-become-lakeland-university-on-july-1|title=Lakeland College to become Lakeland University on July 1|website=lakeland.edu|access-date=2018-03-18}} ==About Lakeland== Lakeland University is a [[Bachelor's degree|bachelor's]] and [[master's degree]]-granting liberal arts institution related to the United Church of Christ with nearly 3,500 students (850 traditional undergraduate students and 2,600 evening, weekend and online students) from 24 countries, 10 on-campus residence halls and more than 30 majors.{{Cite web|url=https://lakeland.edu/Admissions/quick-facts-admissions|title=Quick Facts|website=lakeland.edu|access-date=2018-05-01}} In addition to the main campus in Plymouth, Lakeland has seven evening, weekend and online centers, located in Milwaukee, Madison, Wisconsin Rapids (Central Wisconsin), Chippewa Falls, Fox Cities, Green Bay, Sheboygan.{{Cite web|url=https://lakeland.edu/Evening-Weekend-and-Online/blended#see-our-faq-section|title=BlendEd|website=lakeland.edu|access-date=2018-08-23}} The university also has an international campus in Tokyo, Japan. In the fall of 2017, Lakeland launched a cooperative education model which allows Lakeland students to gain 12-18 months of professional work experience with local companies, along with the ability to earn more than $100,000 to minimize post-graduate student debt.{{Cite news|url=https://lakeland.edu/coop|title=Cooperative Education Program|work=Lakeland University|access-date=2017-10-10|language=en-US}} Men's and women's teams and individuals compete in NCAA Division III baseball, basketball, cross country, football, golf, soccer, softball, tennis, track and field, volleyball and wrestling. ==Athletics== Lakeland University teams participate in the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]]'s [[Division III (NCAA)|Division III]]. The [[Muskellunge|Muskies]] are a member of the [[Northern Athletics Conference|Northern Athletics Collegiate Conference]] (NACC). Lakeland was a former member of the [[Lake Michigan Conference (defunct)|Lake Michigan Conference]] until the spring of 2006. Men's sports include baseball, basketball, cross country, football, golf, soccer, tennis, track & field, volleyball and wrestling. Women's sports include basketball, cross country, golf, soccer, softball, tennis, track & field, volleyball, and Wisconsin's first intercollegiate women's wrestling team.{{Cite web|url=http://lakelandmuskies.com/|title=The Official Athletic Website Of Lakeland College|website=lakelandmuskies.com|language=en|access-date=2017-02-10}} Lakeland's official colors are navy blue and gold.{{Cite web|url=http://www.naccsports.org/members/lakeland/info|title=Lakeland University Muskies|website=Northern Athletics Collegiate Conference|language=en|access-date=2017-02-14}} ==Evening, Weekend & Online== Lakeland University offers 10 undergraduate majors and three graduate degrees. Courses typically meet once per week during evening hours, over 14-week semesters in the fall and spring and over 10-week semesters in the summer. With its BlendEd format, students always have the option of attending classes in person or accessing courses and completing their work entirely online. [[File:MaurizioBolognini.jpg|thumb|Maurizio Bolognini (2004)]]
'''Maurizio Bolognini''' (born July 27, 1952) is a [[conceptual art|post-conceptual]] media artist. His installations are mainly concerned with the aesthetics of [[machine|machines]],<ref>{{citation |title=Machine Art in the Twentieth Century |url=https://mitpress.mit.edu/books/machine-art-twentieth-century |year=2016 |author=Andreas Broeckmann |language=English |publisher=MIT Press |location=Cambridge Ma |isbn=9780262035064 }}, pp. 1, 6, 115-116.</ref> and are based on the minimal and abstract activation of technological processes that are beyond the artist's control,<ref>[[Mario Costa (philosopher)|Mario Costa]] (2003), ''New Technologies''. Artmedia, [[University of Salerno]], Museo del Sannio, pp. 7-12.</ref> at the intersection of [[generative art]], [[public art]] and [[e-democracy]].<ref>Maurizio Bolognini, "De l'interaction à la démocratie. Vers un art génératif post-digital" / [http://www.bolognini.org/lectures/amx.htm "From interactivity to democracy. Towards a post-digital generative art"], Artmedia X Proceedings, Paris, 2010. Also in ''Ethique, esthétique, communication technologique'', Edition L'Harmattan. Paris, 2011, pp. 229-239.</ref>
==Background== Maurizio Bolognini was born in [[Brescia]], Italy. Before working as a media artist, he received degrees in [[urban planning]] and [[social sciences]] from the [[University of Birmingham]], UK, and the [[University IUAV of Venice]]. He later worked extensively as a researcher in the field of structured communication techniques (such as the real-time [[Delphi method]]), and [[electronic democracy]].<ref>{{citation |title=Democrazia elettronica |url=http://www.bolognini.org/bolognini_DE.htm |year=2001 |author=Maurizio Bolognini |language=Italian |publisher=Carocci Editore |location=Rome |isbn=88-430-2035-8 }}. {{citation |title=Arte ipercontemporanea |url=http://www.gangemi.com/scheda.asp?id=8849211147 |year=2007 |author=Simonetta Lux |language=Italian |publisher=Gangemi Editore |location=Rome |isbn=978-88-492-1114-6 }}, pp. 480-481.</ref> His research interests and a wide range of artworks have focused on three main dimensions of digital technologies:<ref>{{citation |title=Postdigitale |url=http://www.bolognini.org/bolognini_PDIG.htm |year=2008 |author=Maurizio Bolognini |language=Italian |publisher=Carocci Editore |location=Rome |isbn=978-88-430-4739-0 }}, chap. 1.</ref>
[[File:Programmed Machines installation by Maurizio Bolognini.jpg|thumb|left|140 px|''Programmed Machines (Sealed Computer series), [[Nice]], France, 1992-97'']] [[File:CAIROG.JPG|thumb|left|140 px|''Interactive installation, Art Palace, [[Cairo]], 2008'']]
— the possibility of delegating his artistic action to the infinite time of the machine, such as in his Programmed Machines. From the beginning (1988), this series introduced the concept of infinity into his work,<ref>{{citation |title=Maurizio Bolognini. Programmed Machines 1990-2005 |year=2005 |author=Sandra Solimano (ed.) |publisher=Villa Croce Museum of Contemporary Art, Neos |location=Genoa |isbn=88-87262-47-0 }}.</ref> and focused on "the experience of the disproportion (and disjunction) between artist and the artwork, which is made possible by computer-based technologies";<ref>Maurizio Bolognini (2008), ''Postdigitale'', Rome: Carocci Editore, p. 24.</ref>
— the space-time flows of technological communication, and the interplay of geographical and electronic space, which gave rise to works such as Altavista (1996),<ref>{{citation |title=Art et Internet |url=http://www.cercledart.com/catalogue_ouvrages/9782_702208649_art_et_internet |year=2008 |author=[[Fred Forest]] |language=French |publisher=Cercle d'art |location=Paris |isbn=978-2-7022-0864-9 }}, pp. 67-71.</ref> Antipodes (1998),<ref>Vincenzo Cuomo, [http://www.kainos.it/numero2/sezioni/ricerche/cuomo01.html "L’altro nella rete"], ''Kainós'', 2, 2003.</ref> and Museophagia (1998–99), in which the use of web-based communication flows focused on their physical infrastructure and was often combined with actions taken over long distance travels;<ref>[[Derrick de Kerckhove]], "Museophagia - The art gallery in the age of its digital reproduction", in Piero Cavellini (ed.) (1999), [http://www.bolognini.org/bolognini_RPT.htm ''Maurizio Bolognini. Raptus''], Brescia: Nuovi Strumenti, pp. 19-25.</ref>
— the introduction of new forms of [[interactive art|interactivity]] based upon structured communication techniques and e-democracy, which he used in installations such as the CIMs (Collective Intelligence Machines, since 2000)<ref>Maurizio Bolognini, "De l'interaction à la démocratie. Vers un art génératif post-digital" / [http://www.bolognini.org/lectures/amx.htm "From interactivity to democracy. Towards a post-digital generative art"], ''Artmedia X Proceedings''. Paris, 2010.</ref> and ICB (Interactive Collective Blue, 2006).<ref>Maurizio Bolognini (2008), ''Postdigitale'', Rome: Carocci Editore, pp. 20-21.</ref>
Some of these works were developed through intense cooperation with [[Artmedia]], the Laboratory of the Aesthetics of Media and Communication, [[University of Salerno]], and the Laboratory Museum of Contemporary Art (MLAC), [[Sapienza University of Rome]]. In 2003 the MLAC published a monograph book on Bolognini’s work.<ref>{{citation |title=Maurizio Bolognini: installazioni, disegni, azioni |year=2003 |author=Domenico Scudero (ed.) |language=Italian |publisher=Lithos |location=Rome |isbn=88-86584-71-7 }}.</ref> In 2004 [[Artmedia]] organized a show which was aimed to highlight a European tendency in new media art, based on the concept of the [[sublime (philosophy)|''technological sublime'']]. The show included works by [[Roy Ascott]] (English), Maurizio Bolognini (Italian), [[Fred Forest]] (French), Richard Kriesche (Austrian) and Mit Mitropoulos (Greek).<ref>Mario Costa (2003), ''New Technologies: Ascott, Bolognini, Forest, Kriesche, Mitropoulos''. Artmedia, [[University of Salerno]], Museo del Sannio.</ref>
==Programmed Machines== [[File:MPTG.JPG|thumb|right|140 px|''Museophagia, 1998-99'']] [[File:IMOLAG.JPG|thumb|right|140 px|''Interactive installation (CIMs series), [[Imola]], Italy, 2006'']] [[File:SCHEMEG.JPG|thumb|right|140 px|''CIMs interaction structure'']]
In 1988, Bolognini began using personal computers to generate flows of continuously expanding random images. In the 1990s, he programmed hundreds of these computers and left them to run ad infinitum (most of these are still working now). About his Programmed Machines he wrote: "I do not consider myself an artist who creates certain images, and I am not merely a conceptual artist. I am one whose machines have actually traced more lines than anyone else, covering boundless surfaces. I am not interested in the formal quality of the images produced by my installations but rather in their flow, their limitlessness in space and time, and the possibility of creating parallel universes of information made up of kilometres of images and infinite trajectories. My installations serve to generate out-of-control infinities."<ref>Maurizio Bolognini (2008), ''Postdigitale'', Rome: Carocci Editore, p. 34. See also Sandra Solimano (ed.) (2005), Maurizio Bolognini. Programmed Machines 1990-2005, Genoa: Villa Croce Museum of Contemporary Art, Neos, p. 15.</ref>
The Programmed Machines (and in particular the Sealed Computers, since 1992, whose monitor buses are closed with wax and whose graphic outputs cannot be displayed) <ref>"The complete inaccessibility of the vast quantity of visual imagery created by the work references a technological sublimity of the void beneath the digital world”, according to {{citation |title=The Cyborg Subject. Reality, Consciousness, Parallax |year=2016 |author=Garfield Benjamin |language=English |publisher=Palgrave McMillan |location=London |isbn=978-1-137-58448-9 }}, p. 86.</ref> are considered among his most significant works.<ref>Andreas Broeckmann, "Image, Process, Performance, Machine: Aspects of an Aesthetics of the Machinic", in {{citation |title=Media Art Histories |url=http://leonardo.info/isast/leobooks/books/grau2.html |year=2007 |author=Oliver Grau (ed.) |publisher=[[MIT Press]] |location=Cambridge |isbn=0-262-07279-3 }}, pp. 204-205. Andreas Broeckmann, [http://www.mikro.in-berlin.de/wiki/tiki-index.php?page=Software+Art "Software Art Aesthetics"], in David Olivier Lartigaud (ed.) (2008) (in French), ''Art orienté programmation''. Paris: [[Sorbonne University]]. Inke Arns (2005), [http://www.uoc.edu/artnodes/espai/eng/art/arns0505.pdf "Code as Performative Speech Act"], ''Artnodes'', 5, [[Open University of Catalonia]]. {{citation |title=Dimenticare l’arte |url=http://www.francoangeli.it/Ricerca/Scheda_Libro.asp?ID=12843&Tipo=Libro&strRicercaTesto=&titolo=dimenticare+l++arte%2E+nuovi+orientamenti+nella+teoria+e+nella+sperimentazione+estetica |year=2006 |author=Mario Costa |language=Italian |publisher=Franco Angeli |location=Milan |isbn=978-88-464-6364-7 }}, pp. 137-138. Simonetta Lux (2007), ''Arte ipercontemporanea'', Rome: Gangemi Editore, pp. 374-393. Domenico Scudero (ed.) (2003), ''Maurizio Bolognini: installazioni, disegni, azioni'', Rome: Lithos, pp. 9-49. Andres Ramirez Gaviria (2004), ''Approaches in Multimedia Art'', New York: New York Arts Books, pp. 33-35. Pedrini, E. (ed.) (2003), ''Maurizio Bolognini: Between Utopia and Infochaos'', New York: Williamsburg Art & Historical Center. {{citation |title=L'oggetto estetico e la critica |year=2007 |author=Mario Costa |language=Italian |publisher=Edisud |location=Salerno |isbn=978-8896-15-4 }}, pp. 31-43. Mario Costa, Vittorio Cafagna (2005), ''Phenomenology of New Tech Arts'', Artmedia, [[University of Salerno]], Department of Philosophy, Department of Mathematics and Informatics, pp. 18-20. [[Robert C. Morgan]], "Maurizio Bolognini: The Problematic of Art", ''Luxflux'', 4, 2004, pp. 94-101.</ref> These Machines were exhibited in many museums and art galleries, in Europe and the United States. In 2003 some sixty Machines were exhibited in three simultaneous shows arranged at the Laboratory Museum of Contemporary Art in Rome, the CACTicino Center for Contemporary Art in Switzerland, and the Williamsburg Art & Historical Center in New York. In 2005 the Villa Croce Museum of Contemporary Art, Genoa, dedicated a retrospective and a monograph to these works.<ref>Sandra Solimano (ed.) (2005), ''Maurizio Bolognini. Programmed Machines 1990-2005'', Genoa: Villa Croce Museum of Contemporary Art, Neos.</ref>
Since 2000, Bolognini has concentrated on combining the Programmed Machines with communication devices, as in the Collective Intelligence Machines. These are interactive installations connecting some of his generative machines to the mobile telephone network,<ref>Maurizio Bolognini, "The SMSMS Project: Collective Intelligence Machines in the Digital City", ''Leonardo''/[[MIT Press]], 37/2, 2004, pp. 147-149; Maurizio Bolognini, "Infoinstallations et ville numérique", ''Ligeia. Dossiers sur l’art'', 45-48. Paris, 2003, pp. 57-60.</ref> to allow a real-time Delphi-like interaction by members of the public. These installations delegate choices to both electronic devices and processes of communication and e-democracy with the aim of involving the audience in new forms of “generative, interactive and public art”.<ref>Maurizio Bolognini (2010), "De l'interaction à la démocratie. Vers un art gėnėratif post-digital", Artmedia X Proceedings, Paris. See also {{citation |title=Digital Arts. An Introduction to New Media |year=2014 |author= C. Hope, J. Ryan |language=English |publisher=Bloomsbury |location=New York |isbn=9781780933290 }}, ch. 9: “Maurizio Bolognini revises the very notion of a digital device to encompass hardware, software ''and the public''. Postdigital artists see digital devices as enmeshed in social processes and patterns. […] New modes of participation offer a variety of possibilities for digital art in which there is a shift from weak modes of public interaction to stronger modes that promote democracy and public decision-making. To be sure, digital art in the future will utilize participatory technologies and mobile communications to a greater extent.”</ref>
Maurizio Bolognini's work has been considered relevant to the theory of the [[sublime (philosophy)|''technological sublime'']]<ref>(2003), [[Mario Costa (philosopher)|Mario Costa]], ''New Technologies: Ascott, Bolognini, Forest, Kriesche, Mitropoulos'', Artmedia, University of Salerno, Museo del Sannio, pp. 7-12; Andreas Broeckmann, "Software Art Aesthetics", in David Olivier Lartigaud (ed.) (2008), ''Art orienté programmation'', Paris: Sorbonne University.</ref> and the aesthetics of flux (as opposed to the aesthetics of form),<ref>Mario Costa (2006), ''Dimenticare l’arte'', Milan: Franco Angeli; {{citation |title=Arte contemporanea ed estetica del flusso |year=2010 |author=Mario Costa |language=Italian |publisher=Edizioni Mercurio |location=Vercelli |isbn=978-88-95522-61-6 }}, pp. 123-124.</ref> and has been seen as a further development of [[conceptual art]] within neo-technological art.<ref>Sandra Solimano, "Metaphors and Moves", in ''Maurizio Bolognini. Personal Infinity'', Brescia: Nuovi Strumenti, pp. 17-18; Robert C. Morgan, "Maurizio Bolognini: The Problematic of Art", Luxflux, 4, 2004, p. 96.</ref>

{{Infobox spacecraft instrument | Name = MicrOmega-IR | Image = | Caption = | Operator = [[European Space Agency]] | Manufacturer = ''Institut d'Astrophysique Spatiale'', of the [[Centre national de la recherche scientifique|CNRS]] | Type = [[Hyperspectral imaging|Infrared hyperspectral microscope]] | Function = Subsurface composition | Mission_Duration = ≥ 7 months{{cite journal |title=Habitability on Early Mars and the Search for Biosignatures with the ExoMars Rover |journal=Astrobiology |first=Jorge L. |last=Vago |display-authors=etal |volume=17 |issue=6-7 |pages=471-510 |date=July 2017 |doi=10.1089/ast.2016.1533 |bibcode=2017AsBio..17..471V}} | Began = | Ceased = | Webpage = | Mass = ≈2 kg | Dimensions = | Power_consumption = | Resolution = | Spectral_Band = | Data_Rate = | Spacecraft = [[ExoMars rover]] | SC_Operator = [[European Space Agency]] | Launch = July 2020{{cite press release |url=http://www.esa.int/For_Media/Press_Releases/Second_ExoMars_mission_moves_to_next_launch_opportunity_in_2020 |title=Second ExoMars mission moves to next launch opportunity in 2020 |publisher=European Space Agency |date=2 May 2016 |accessdate=2 May 2016}} | Rocket = [[Proton (rocket family)|Proton rocket]] | Launch_Site = | COSPAR = }} [[File:Papakolea Beach sand high mag 052915.jpg|thumb|Grains of Earth olivine, one of the minerals MicroOmega is designed to detect]] '''MicrOmega-IR''' is an [[Hyperspectral imaging|infrared hyperspectral microscope]] that is part of the science payload on board the European [[ExoMars rover]],[https://www.space.com/34664-exomars-facts.html ExoMars: Searching for Life on Mars]. Elizabeth Howell, ''Space.com''. March 15, 2017. tasked to search for [[biosignature]]s on Mars. The rover is planned to [[Mars landing|land on Mars]] in 2021. MicrOmega-IR will analyse ''[[in situ]]'' the powder material derived from crushed samples collected by the [[ExoMars (rover)#Core drill|rover's core drill]].{{cite journal |url=http://esamultimedia.esa.int/multimedia/publications/ESA-Bulletin-155/offline/download.pdf |title=ExoMars: ESA's Next Step in Mars Exploration |journal=Bulletin |publisher=European Space Agency |first1=Jorge |last1=Vago |first2=Olivier |last2=Witasse |first3=Pietro |last3=Baglioni |first4=Albert |last4=Haldemann |first5=Giacinto |last5=Gianfiglio |first6=Thierry |last6=Blancquaert |first7=Don |last7=McCoy |first8=Rolf |last8=de Groot |display-authors=5 |issue=155 |pages=12–23 |date=August 2013}}{{cite journal |title=Infrared Spectrometer for ExoMars: A Mast-Mounted Instrument for the Rover |journal=Astrobiology |first=Oleg I. |last=Korablev |display-authors=etal |volume=17 |issue=6-7 |pages=542-564 |date=July 2017 |doi=10.1089/ast.2016.1543 |bibcode=2017AsBio..17..542K}} ==Development== The ''MicrOmega'' [[mnemonic]] is derived from its French name ''Micro observatoire pour la mineralogie, l'eau, les glaces et l'activité''; IR stands for [[infrared]]. It was developed by France's ''Institut d'Astrophysique Spatiale'' at the [[Centre national de la recherche scientifique|CNRS]]. France has also flown MicrOmega on other missions such as the 2011 [[Fobos-Grunt]] and the ''[[Hayabusa2]]'' MASCOT mobile lander currently exploring [[162173 Ryugu|asteroid Ryugu]].[https://mascot.cnes.fr/en/MASCOT/GP_micromega.htm MicroMega Instrument for MASCOT]. [[CNES]], France. August 26, 2016. Accessed: 21 July 2018. France is also developing a variant called MacrOmega Near-IR Spectrometer for the [[Martian Moons Exploration]] (MMX) lander, a Japanese [[sample-return mission]] to Mars' moon [[Phobos (moon)|Phobos]].[http://www.isas.jaxa.jp/en/topics/files/MMX170412_EN.pdf#page=19 Martian Moons eXploration (MMX) Mission Overview]. (PDF). [[JAXA]]. 10 April 2017. The [[Principal Investigator]] of the MicrOmega-IR for the ExoMars rover is Jean-Pierre Bibring, a French astronomer and planetary scientist at the ''Institut d'Astrophysique Spatiale''. Co-PIs are astrobiologists Frances Westall and Nicolas Thomas.[http://exploration.esa.int/mars/45103-rover-instruments/ The ExoMars Rover Instrument Suite - MicrOmega]. [[European Space Agency]]. Published: 25 August 2017. MicrOmega was developed by a consortium including:{{Cite journal|last=Vaitua|first=Leroi|last2=Bibring|first2=Jean-Pierre|last3=Berthé|first3=Michel|date=2017-11-21|title=MicrOmega IR: a new infrared hyperspectral imaging microscope or in situ analysis|url=https://www.spiedigitallibrary.org/conference-proceedings-of-spie/10566/105662B/MicrOmega-IR--a-new-infrared-hyperspectral-imaging-microscope-or/10.1117/12.2308234.full?SSO=1|volume=10566|doi=10.1117/12.2308234.full}} *[[:fr:Institut d'astrophysique spatiale|IAS]] (Orsay, France) {{flagicon|France}} *[[Paris Observatory|LESIA]] (Meudon, France){{flagicon|France}} * CBM (Orléans, France), {{flagicon|France}} *[[University of Bern|University Of Bern]] (Bern, Switzerland) {{flagicon|Switzerland}} * [[Russian Space Research Institute]] (IKI) (Moscow, Russia) {{flagicon|Russia}} ==Overview== {| class="wikitable floatright" ! MicrOmega-IR !! Parameter/units |- | Type || [[Hyperspectral imaging|Infrared hyperspectral microscope]] |- | Manufacturer || ''Institut d'Astrophysique Spatiale'',
of the [[Centre national de la recherche scientifique|CNRS]] |- | Spectral range || 0.9–4 μm |- | Spectral sampling || 20/cm from 0.95 μm to 3.65 μm |- | Imaging resolution || 20  μm2/pixel |- | [[Field of view]] || 5 × 5  mm2 |- | Mass || ≈ {{conv|2|kg}} |} MicrOmega-IR is a visible and [[Hyperspectral imaging|infrared hyperspectral microscope]] that is designed to characterize the texture and composition of crushed samples presented to the instrument.[https://www.liebertpub.com/doi/abs/10.1089/ast.2016.1642 The MicrOmega Investigation Onboard ExoMars]. Jean-Pierre Bibring, Vincent Hamm, Cédric Pilorget, Jorge L. Vago, and the MicrOmega Team. ''Astrobiology'', Vol. 17, No. 6-7. 1 July 2017. {{doi|10.1089/ast.2016.1642}}. Its objective is to study mineral grain assemblages in detail to try to unravel their geological origin, structure and composition, including potential [[Organic compound|organics]]. These data will be vital for interpreting past and present geological processes and environments on Mars. Because MicrOmega-IR is an imaging instrument, it can also be used to identify grains that are particularly interesting, and assign them as targets for [[ExoMars (rover)#Pasteur instrument suite|Raman]] and [[Mars Organic Molecule Analyzer|MOMA]] observations. It is composed of 2 microscopes: MicrOmega/VIS has a spatial sampling of approximately 4 μm, working in 4 colors in the visible range. The other one is the MicrOmega/NIR hyperspectral microscope working in the spectral range 0.95 μm - 3.65 μm with a spatial sampling of 20 μm per pixel.[https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0032063309000026 Micromega/IR: Design and status of a near-infrared spectral microscope for in situ analysis of Mars samples]. Vaitua Leroi, Jean-Pierre Bibring, Michel Berthe. ''Planetary and Space Science'', Volume 57, Issues 8–9, July 2009, Pages 1068-1075. {{doi|10.1016/j.pss.2008.12.014}} Its main supporting components include: [http://exploration.esa.int/mars/47868-micromega-instrument-prototype/ MicrOmega Instrument Prototype]. [[European Space Agency]]. 12 October 2015. *A [[monochromator]] based on an [[Acousto-optic modulator]] illumination system. *Infrared magnification optics. *Infrared focal plane. *The thermal control system. *The sample container. The IR instrument uses a [[Mercury cadmium telluride|HgCdTe]] (Mercury-Cadmium-Telluride) matrix detector, the [[Sofradir]] Mars SW 320 x 256 pixels.{{Cite journal|last=Vaitua|first=Leroi|last2=Bibring|first2=Jean-Pierre|last3=Berthé|first3=Michel|date=2017-11-21|title=MicrOmega IR: a new infrared hyperspectral imaging microscope or in situ analysis|url=https://www.spiedigitallibrary.org/conference-proceedings-of-spie/10566/105662B/MicrOmega-IR--a-new-infrared-hyperspectral-imaging-microscope-or/10.1117/12.2308234.full?SSO=1|volume=10566|doi=10.1117/12.2308234.full}} Examples of materials for identification, if present:{{Cite journal|last=Leroi|first=Vaitua|last2=Bibring|first2=Jean-Pierre|last3=Berthe|first3=Michel|date=July 2009|title=Micromega/IR: Design and status of a near-infrared spectral microscope for in situ analysis of Mars samples|url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2009P&SS...57.1068L|journal=Planetary and Space Science|language=en|volume=57|issue=8-9|pages=1068–1075|doi=10.1016/j.pss.2008.12.014|issn=0032-0633|bibcode=2009P&SS...57.1068L}} *[[pyroxene]] *[[olivine]] *[[Iron(III) oxide|ferric oxide]]s *hydrated phyllosilicates *[[Sulfate|sulfates]] *[[Carbonates on Mars|carbonates]] *ices *organics (organic as in [[organic chemistry]]) ==See also== * [[Astrobiology]] * [[Life on Mars]] *[[Mars Multispectral Imager for Subsurface Studies]] (Another ExoMars drill-related instrument) ==References== {{reflist}} {{Exomars}} {{Satellite and spacecraft instruments}} {{Astrobiology}} {{European Space Agency}} {{Use British English|date=July 2018}} [[Category:ExoMars]] [[Category:Mars imagers]] [[Category:Astrobiology]] [[Category:Space science experiments]]

(2011)<ref name="pmid21109531"/> |released = 2010 |standard = |format = |url = http://mips.helmholtz-muenchen.de |download = |webservice = |sql = |sparql = |webapp = |standalone = |license = |versioning = |frequency = |curation = |bookmark = |version= }}The '''Munich Information Center for Protein Sequences''' ('''MIPS''') is a [[research center]] hosted at the Institute for Bioinformatics (IBI) at Neuherberg, [[Germany]] with a focus on [[genome]] oriented [[bioinformatics]], in particular on the systematic analysis of genome information including the development and application of bioinformatics methods in genome annotation, [[gene expression]] analysis and [[proteomics]]. [[File:Nasothek-2.jpg|thumb|Nasothek displaying marble body parts once used to "repair" antique statuary.]]A '''nasothek''' (from the Latin ''{{lang|la|nasus}}'' "nose" and Greek {{lang|grc|θήκη}} "container") is a collection of sculpted noses.
==Carlsberg display of restoration noses== The [[Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek]] museum in Copenhagen has a nasothek collection that displays restored noses that were removed from portrait busts and statues after changes in the museum's [[art restoration]] policies.<ref name=Huizing>{{cite book|title=Klinik der menschlichen Sinne|year=2008|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-3-211-76632-3|pages=66|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XaOg_nkDQR0C|author=E.H. Huizing|chapter=The Nose and Beyond—No Nose|accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref><ref name=restor>{{cite book|title=History of restoration of ancient stone sculptures|year=2003|publisher=Getty Publications|isbn=978-0-89236-723-8|pages=207–224|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZNAVlaA6FuUC|author=Mette Moltesen|editor=Janet Burnett Grossman|chapter=Fifty years of restoration work in the Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek|display-editors=etal}}</ref> The noses, some made of marble and others of plaster, were all originally exhibited on the Greek and Roman statues in the glyptotek itself.<ref>Sign in Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek under its nasothek display</ref>
[[File:Nasothek.JPG|thumb|left|Detail: A closer look at the Copenhagen Nasothek display shows wide variety in surface textures and style.]]The [[Marble#Sculpture|white marble]] favored by Classical sculptors is easily broken, and many antique statues have been damaged since their creation by accidents, [[iconoclasm]], or vandalism. During the 19th century, it was common practice for museums to exhibit such marble sculptures in a "restored" state, with damaged parts repaired or reconstructed to make the statue look as much as possible as it did when it was first created. The noses of antique statues are especially likely to be damaged or missing, so many Greek or Roman statues acquired new noses during this era. Modern exhibition practice may differ from museum to museum. The minimalist approach prescribes removing such 19th-century additions in the interest of authenticity, as has been done in Copenhagen.<ref name=Getty>{{cite web|title=Getty Exhibition Spotlights Practices In Antiquities Conservation|url=http://www.getty.edu/news/press/center/hope_hygieia_release_040208.html|publisher=J. Paul Getty Museum|accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref>
The Ny Carlsberg museum, which has an extensive collection of Greek and Roman marble statues, participated both in 19th-century restoration and in 20th-century "de-restoration." As a result, many Roman portrait heads are now noseless again, with their restored noses removed to the museum's nasothek.<ref name=restor/>
The museum display explains its contents in both Danish and English. The English description says, "The word ''nasothek'' means a collection of noses, in analogy with ''{{linktext|discotheque}}'', a collection of records."<ref name=restor/> The Danish explanation compares "nasotek" (Danish equivalent of "nasothek") to "{{linktext|bibliotek}}", a collection of books.<ref name=restor/>
==Lund display of plaster casts of noses== [[File:Nya NasoteketCropped.jpg|180px|thumb|right|Display of plaster casts of noses at [[Lund University]]]] The ''Nasoteket'' at [[Lund University]] in Sweden consists of a display of more than 100 plaster casts of noses, including a cast of the silver nose of [[Tycho Brahe]].<ref name=obscura>{{cite web|title=The Nose Academy|url=http://atlasobscura.com/place/nose-academy|publisher=Atlas Obscura|accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref>

It was first established in 1921. Subsidiary institutes operate in each of the major Korean fisheries.
The NFRDI is headquartered in Gijang-eup, [[Gijang-gun]], northern [[Busan]].

<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:nurp.gif|right|thumb]] --> The '''National Undersea Research Program''' (NURP) is a [[Federal government of the United States|U.S. government]] program that operates six facilities for undersea research, including the world's only permanent undersea research facility, [[Aquarius (laboratory)|Aquarius]]. The program is operated under the auspices of the [[Office of Oceanic and Atmospheric Research]], a division of the [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] (NOAA). Each center is funded by a grant from NOAA. Projects are chosen based upon peer review.
==List of regional centers== * [[National Undersea Research Center for Hawaii and the Western Pacific]] - [[University of Hawaii|University of Hawaii's]] [[Hawaii Undersea Research Laboratory]] (HURL) * [[National Undersea Research Center for the West Coast and Polar Regions]] [[University of Alaska Fairbanks]] (UAF) School of Fisheries and Ocean Sciences * [[National Undersea Research Center for the North Atlantic and Great Lakes]]- [[University of Connecticut]], Avery Point * [[National Undersea Research Center for the Middle Atlantic Bight]] - [[Institute of Marine and Coastal Sciences]] (IMCS) at [[Rutgers University]], [[New Brunswick, New Jersey|New Brunswick]], New Jersey * [[National Undersea Research Center for the Southeastern United States and Gulf of Mexico]] - [[University of North Carolina at Wilmington]] * [[National Undersea Research Center for the Caribbean]] - [[Caribbean Marine Research Center]] (CMRC), [[Tequesta, Florida|Tequesta]], FL
==External links== * [http://www.nurp.noaa.gov/ NOAA's Undersea Research Program]
